Based on the search results, I found extensive information about how "Brave New World" is referenced in contemporary political commentary and debates. Here's what the search revealed:

## Political Commentary and References to "Brave New World"

Contemporary political commentators widely interpret Aldous Huxley's "Brave New World" as a cautionary tale about totalitarian ideology, with the novel portraying a totalitarian nightmare to warn readers about the dangers of state control that revokes civil liberties.

### Conservative Perspectives

Conservatives particularly embrace "Brave New World" as illustrating many concepts they argue against, using the novel to explore potentially damaging consequences of these ideas and pointing others to it to understand the deficiencies of certain political concepts. Conservative analysis focuses on how the novel shows the consequences of having a state so large that it overtakes individual choice and becomes the only institution in existence, while conservatives value human beings' capacity to make their own choices and treasure the role of institutions.

The book is seen by conservatives as condemning "central planning, unrestrained consumerism, absolute liberty and the erosion of the family" while advocating for "a reasonable middle ground: a government large enough to maintain order but which is sufficiently restrained in size and scope to allow for individual expression".

### Liberal Critiques and Self-Reflection

Liberal commentators have engaged in self-criticism, with some arguing that "Brave New World = Liberalism" in terms of dystopian outcomes, suggesting that the novel represents what liberal dystopia might look like, with Silicon Valley elites and corporate leaders resembling Huxley's dystopian vision.

Critics note that "terrifying liberal political ideals look to many people," especially those in poverty, as the liberal future "looks great for anybody who can buy their way into an elite college education, and a position in the techno-corporate hierarchy," making it "still a horrifying option to most of us".

### Huxley's Own Political Evolution

Huxley himself identified as both a classical liberal and conservative, stating "Only a large-scale popular movement towards decentralization and self-help can arrest the present tendency toward statism" and noting that "For the last 30 years there have been no conservatives; there have been only nationalistic radicals of the right and nationalistic radicals of the left".

### Broader Political Discourse

The novel has become part of broader political debate games where different groups blame potential dystopian futures on their political enemies, with "George Orwell's 1984" being used as "an allegory for the evils of capitalism / communism / socialism / conservatism" depending on who's discussing it.

Political analysts distinguish between different dystopian visions, noting that while "Orwell wrote Nineteen Eighty Four as a commentary on contemporary society," Huxley "examined contemporary social trends and predicted where they would lead (with surprising accuracy)".

The novel continues to be referenced across the political spectrum as a warning about different forms of social control, with both conservatives and liberals finding relevance in its themes for contemporary political debates about government power, individual liberty, and social control.
